Posts.Title: When to go back to work

Posts.Content: The one thing I have learned from my journey is this: We all tend to want to compare our situation with another person's; especially when the circumstances are similar, and when their results are good and the outlook positive, and that's not a bad thing; it is human nature for us to try and provide ourselves with answers that are emotionally satisfying when our very lives or at the very least the quality of our lives, are on the table. Yes, you will see some guys what are evaluated at a 4+3, then on second opinion, downgraded to 3+3, but don't forget, it works the other way, too, and that 3+4 can turn out to be a 4+5. That being said, I think it is still the best course to err on the side of caution when deciding on a course of treatment. You can't count on the post-op pathology being consistent with what they find during a biopsy. I am no surgeon but the conventional wisdom dictates that, when (and if) necessary, radiation can follow surgery more effectively than surgery can follow radiation. That, combined with the fact that most who post here have had a considerable return to normalcy post surgery, would make a good case for surgery as a solution. Good luck, friend, and, I agree, you have stumbled upon a really great bunch of guys who will be an invaluable resource. Best regards, DD

Posts.Title: When to go back to work

Posts.Content: Hey guys, Had my surgery on Tuesday night....Doc said that all went well, both nerve bundles spared, he took quite a few lymph nodes but had planned on doing that anyway due to my high PSA. There was no indication to him that any were positive, but we will see when I follow up with him in six weeks to review, check levels, and strategize treatment.. Surgery was not very traumatic. Last thing I remembered was telling the anesthesiologist that my hand was burning a little at the IV site. Next thing I knew I was in recovery, and feeling pretty close to normal, chatting with the nurses. Woke up on day One felt pretty well; got up and walked around the nurse's station for a good bit, went to a catheter care class, ate some solid food. My creatinine was high and they were a bit concerned about kidney function so kept me an extra day. Day 2 was not so great...big time gas cramps and bladder spasms, unbelievable pain and not even morphine can touch it. Spasms mixed with horrible, vivid dreams all night, and no sleep to speak of. Later on after I woke up, I finally passed gas for the first time and I farted so long and so hard that I almost forgot my birthday.....that helped tremendously with the gas pains AND the bladder spasms....they are now only maybe 10% of what they were and I just grit my teeth until they pass. They let me go go home afternoon of Day 2, with both a Foley catheter AND a wound drain catheter in place, and I tell you it is a lot to manage. I took a shower yesterday and it felt wonderful but the whole ordeal took more than an hour. It is quite difficult to try and keep everything clean and sterile, but so far I guess I am doing okay. I had to re-dress the drain site after the shower and didn't have a clue what I was doing and last night the drain stopped pulling suction in the middle of the night and the fluid from the wound site ran down my leg and I woke up wet with gut juice at 3 a.m. this morning and had to go in and try to patch it all up and keep it all clean. Pain in the ass! Anyway, just wanted to let you guys know I made it out the other side - a little worse for wear but still vertical. Will write more later, have to go empty my drain. Regards, DD

Posts.Title: The Prostate has left the building.

Posts.Content: I understand that maybe it can't be that accurately measured, BUT, then again, there does seem to be these super-sensitive assays..........it occurs to me that, if your PSA was actually 0.0.......ABSOLUTE zero......your treatment would be over. I mean, if there were absolutely NO PSA in your body, wouldn't that make the chance of biochemical reoccurrence impossible? Doesn't PSA come from prostate cells? So if there is no PSA.......how could it ever increase? Where would more come from? So, all of these folks who have been told 0.0, but to come back in three months and have it checked again....why would you need it checked again if it was indeed 0.0? Was it ever REALLY 0.0? I for one think it is a little misleading to tell a patient his PSA Level is 0.0, when the reality is there IS a detectable reading but one that is considered clinically insignificant? Why stress people out like this? Regards, DD

Posts.Content: What did you guys do? I am two weeks past diagnosis. Bone scan and abdominal CT scan coming up on the 22nd. I am worried sick and have no appetite. Losing weight. I am drinking WAY more than I should...somewhere between a bottle and two bottles of wine a night. I have Xanax but don't want benzo addiction on top of everything else so I limit to .25 a day. I take the Xanax after I get home from work and then have a couple of glasses of wine on top of that...keeps me from doing too much of one or the other. At the same time, I work 6 days a week as a project manager for a +$million dollar project working 14 hour days and haven't even told my work yet about the diagnosis...they are laying people off every day because of the oil prices... I am alone..married but we are separated and if the love left there is from having children together, and not much else. There is no partner or intimacy in my life. Yeah, I have considered that this is too much information for an internet forum, but it is what it is, and I need some help. I could go on, but the point is...how much stress can a person handle? What did YOU do? I was on anti-depressants once (Cymbalta) for PTSD and I had to kick them on my own because the doctor had intended for me to be on them for the rest of my life! It was horrific and I am very reluctant to consider antidepressants again..EVER. Thanks for listening. Regards, DD

Posts.Title: A Return to Continence

Posts.Content: Well, I went to bed at around 1100 and woke up with very unfamiliar abdominal cramps at around 0100. I got up and walked to the toilet and to my great surprise released what must have been a pint of urine, which relieved the cramp. I had a pad in and it was a little bit moist but far from being soaked, and everything else was dry. I did this same thing three more times during the night and so got through it this morning having only used one pad for the night. This gives me great hope. What I am taking away here so far is that all of the physical indicators are different; nothing feels like it did before. This urge to urinate doesn't feel anything like the OLD urge to urinate....new nerves, new muscles? Thanks for being there to share this with! DD

Posts.Title: Diet changes / diet recommendations for advanced prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Remember the old thought exercise, Schrodinger's Cat, where a cat is place in a box with a radioactive substance, a Geiger counter, a hammer, and a vial of poison? The box was rigged so that the radioactive material, which had a 50/50 chance of emitting radiation in the course of one hour, if the substance DID emit radiation it would pe picked up by the geiger counter, which in turn was rigged to drop the hammer onto the glass vile of poison and kill the cat......but, simply by observing the sealed box, tha exact state of the cat could not be determined, and so for all practical purposes, the cat was both alive and dead at the same time, until someone actually opened the box and observed the system. I find that having PCa is a lot like being Schrodinger's Cat.People, with all of their good intentions, congratulate you on being cured, because, in the here and now, you have had the cancer removed, and your PSA is non- detectable....but what the Pca patient himself deals with is the spectre of a re-occurrence, and the plain reality that no one is really a cancer survivor until the day they die of something else. Where you wind up finding the most comfort is in knowing that whatever the ultimate outcome, you have improved your chance for a good prognosis by leaps and bounds in taking the actions you have taken. Best regards, DD

Posts.Title: Where in The World is Jim215?

Posts.Content: I have to agree with Highlander. I spent a lot of time looking for the information that would give me the most emotionally satisfying answers; the answers that could help explain away the obvious symptoms and helped me to believe that all was well. The price I paid for that time was months of anxiety. I also had a "clear" 14-core biopsy and a "negative" T3 MRI before I was finally diagnosed with cancer. Let's be honest.....if it walks like a duck, and looks like a duck, and quacks like a duck, it's usually a duck. If I were you I would get the biopsy, and I would ask about a fusion-guided biopsy which is preceded by an MRI which will be used to pinpoint areas of interest during the biopsy. To me, that gives you the most bang for your buck....and you will have the MRI images as a baseline for future studies, or, for a second opinion. My diagnosis happened when a second radiologist reviewed my MRI that the first radiologist said was "normal". I would also ask for a PCA-3 test and see how you score on that one. What I wouldn't do is do nothing. Good luck, DD

Posts.Title: Considering delaying biopsy. Thoughts, opinons welcome.

Posts.Content: Hello, Hilander, Don't go nuts reading statistics and whatnot at this point, looking for some comfort (or worse, some reason to be paranoid) in the probabilities. Statistics mean a LOT more when you're talking about a thousand guys than they do when you're talking about one. I , for one, would ask the doctor if there would be any argument for doing an MRI first and using the MRI images to guide the biopsy to areas of interest that may be identified in the prostate. It also establishes a baseline for future image studies if this DOES turn into a thing. As far as your question about the probability of cancer, I'm sure you understand that is certainly in the realm of possibilities, but temper that with the fact that so is a complete cure, provided it is contained and not too advanced. Let us know how it goes, man. Regards, DD
Posts.Title: Probability?

Posts.Content: Hello, I had my RALRP on 9 June of this year, so I am pretty much five months out. My experience with continence post-surgery was comparatively good, I had pads ready at home but never really needed them; I just had the occasional drop or two (probably the same as I had BEFORE surgery, but wasn't so keenly aware or obsessive about it) and, on a few occasions, a bona fide squirt of very small volume. I immediately went to shields, just as a precaution, and at six weeks they were gone, too. So, overall, I have been very fortunate and it certainly was a blessing that I am thankful for.....I know that for most of us, the concern over a return to continence is foremost in our minds, even, in most cases ahead of sexual function. All that being said, I have never really had a return to a normal pattern. I still have days where I feel myself consciously clenching against some "ghost" urge, and occasionally the sensation that I have leaked, when in reality I have not. I can very honestly say that some days are a lot better than others....some days I am barely conscious of what's going on down there, and some days I am much too aware. It is also a mystery to me why function is SO different at night than during the day. I am getting up right at three times a night, roughly every 2 1/2 hrs, and completely emptying with a flow like a horse. During the day, I sometimes feel like there is a column of urine trapped in the urethra, and occasionally I get a stinging sensation at the end of the penis, which also mimics a leak....but it's not. Never is. My stream during the day is all over the place, sometimes as strong as it is at night, and other times a will have strong urgency and only deliver a small payload with a weak stream. Anyone else experience these sort of inconsistencies? Like I say, I hate to bitch, but you know how much misery loves company...... Thanks and regards, DD

Posts.Title: Probability?

Posts.Content: Your "signals" from your body letting you know when you have to go are going to be different now. It takes a little time to learn the new language. Sounds to me like you are doing pretty much normal...but keep in mind that the real measure is where you are after a year, and as many different opinions as you might get on any OTHER aspect of this procedure, that is one thing that all doctors seem to be consistent in in their thinking. Some people get there quicker than others, but the overall percentage of guys returning to a satisfactory degree of continence is OVER 90%. Don't make the mistake of measuring your results against someone else's...it is a useless exercise and means nothing. Every case is different. As far as doing this or that sooner than they recommend, well...you're a grown up, you can pretty much do what you want, but there are reasons for their recommendations, and if you get ahead of yourself and blow something up before it is completely healed, then YOU will have changed the course of your recovery, and usually for the worse. Personally, I went back to work about two weeks too early, and I really regretted it at the time; I think it took me a LOT longer to heal and get back to normal as a result...my reward for being hardheaded. You're doing fine, man - hang in there. Best regards, DD

Posts.Content: Even before I wound up having prostate issues, I had heard about how great cranberry juice was for keeping the urinary tract healthy. I attempted to self medicate, administering a solution of 6 oz. of cranberry juice with 2 oz. of premium vodka poured over ice in a tall glass, with a squeeze of lime, some four to five times each evening, as needed, which turned out to be an effective anti-depressant, but I didn't see a lot of beneficial effect on the urinary tract. So now, I'm adding to the regimen. I have been reading up on these cranberry pills and people are using phrases like "miracle drug" to describe the benefit. Apparently it has some effect on the bladder walls and the lining of the urethra which helps to keep those areas free of bacteria which may lead to UTI's. Has anyone heard anything for or against these cranberry pills? They're cheap enough, so I think I am going to give them a whirl. I'll let you know how it turns out, just wanted to see if anyone else had any experience with them. Thanks and regards, DD

Posts.Content: I hope it's not the case with you, but I had a clean 16 core biopsy with a PSA of 17 anda year later, a PI-RADS 1 MRI with a PSA of 27. I took the exact same images to a different doctor and was called in two days later for a fusion guided Biposy which found clinical Gleason 7 (4+3). Post-op path later revealed Gleason (4+5). I would get to the bottom of it if I were you. You may also want to speak to someone about a PCA3 test; it is a taken on a urine sample after a "rigorous" DRE - looks for genetic markers specifically from prostate cancer cells. Best check it out, Brother....resist the urge to cling to what makes you feel like everything is going to be okay. Find out for sure...get to the bottom of it. Good luck, and best regards, DD
Posts.Title: A.S. for 3 years - Now a mystery

Posts.Title: Very Best Holiday Wishes

Posts.Content: I had a prostate MRI done in February. The cost was $974. Oddly enough, the clinic had a "cash price" page which offered the same procedure for $625. When I asked why I was being charged so much more, I was told it was because "I had insurance". I said well, what if i just pay the cash price...the response? "Then it won't count towards your deductible". I'm not making this up. To make matters worse, the first doctor who read the study scored it to be clear of any indication of cancer or even abnormal cells. (PI RADS 1). A month later the doctor who read it at M.D. Anderson found "areas of interest" and ordered a fusion biopsy which they did two weeks ago. They found Gleason 3+4. Hard to know who or what to trust in this game, from my experience so far - I've had a clean biopsy AND clean MRI, and countless "unremarkable" DRE's before being diagnosed. I have a "New Member" type post with the whole sordid story LOL. Good luck, and best regards, DD

Posts.Title: 74, Gleason 9, going for surgery

Posts.Content: I am almost at three months (4 days away) and I am completely dry, but what has been happening to me in the last month are these "ghost " feelings of having had a squirt when you really haven't. You also have to remember that old rhyme we all heard, all our lives...."No matter how you jump and dance, the last few drops fall in your pants". The valve is NOT at the end of the penis......it's back a good ways, so it stands to reason that when the valve closes there will be some urine trapped in the urethra that will eventually run out by gravity and create a wet spot on your drawers...probably has been doing it your whole life but you only noticed it since this cancer business came up. Regards, DD

Posts.Title: How long after the drips started???

Posts.Content: Firemedic; There are a LOT of confusing and even conflicting opinions about this disease. To really evaluate your situation right now would be to consider the TOTALITY of what you have determined; and to take all of those elements in context - a guy with a PSA of XX at the age of XX with a family history of XX had a biopsy which revealed adenocarcinoma of Gleason grade XX in XX of XX biopsies taken, of which XX% of XX cores were positive, and a prostate which was XX in size. It is ALL of these XX's, and maybe a few that I missed, that have to be taken into consideration in putting together a battle plan for your paricular disease. To me, at this point, I would consider the most important thing finding a doctor you have confidence in so that you don't have to second guess everything he tells you, and ASK QUESTIONS until you are satisfied with his reasoning for doing what he is suggesting you do. The Walsh book is as near a gold standard as we have to educate ourselves, but among doctors there are some points of contention even in that book and as protocols and techniques continue to evolve, it is what we should all expect and even hope for...giant steps are taken every day in the treatment of this disease. Gleason 6, in particular, is a tough row to hoe.....you will hear "No man dies from a Gleason 6" but at the same time you will notice how many forum members here had Gleason 6 and decided on RALRP anyway.Why would they do that if Gleason 6 never kills anybody? You will even hear that Gleason 6 never evolves into a higher grade of cancer. So what's up, fellas? Fact is, and this trumps everything, you don't really KNOW what you have until they cut it out of you, and quite often (around 50% of the time) once they get in there, they upgrade your Gleason score because biopsies are misleading one way or the other about 40% of the time because they either miss the tumor OR miss the more SERIOUS tumor which might lay right next to that Gleason 6. All the more reason to have a doctor you trust like a brother. Hitch your star to that wagon and get rid of that shit if that's what he thinks is best for you...then don't look back. Very excellent chance you will be whole, you will be fine. Don't throw away a big portion of your life because you're isolated from the people that love you because of anxiety and depression....if you let that happen you will NEVER get it back. Good luck brother, DD

Posts.Title: Diagnosed today, What do the number mean?

Posts.Content: When I had my MRI done, the web site for the lab had a page of published "cash" prices for the procedures. My procedure was listed as $429.00. After the procedure, they gave me the bill;;;for $1100.00. I asked why I was paying more than their published cash price, and was told it was because I had insurance....so I said okay, well, I am opting NOT to use my insurance. Then I was told if I did that, it would NOT count toward my deductible. True story. Health care in America is a major embarrassment, and the ACA has turned out to be just a re-distribution of wealth in that the prices and penalties paid by those who HAVE are now subsidizing those who HAVE NOT. I will tell you another little story. I was unemployed for a while and was having terrible stomach problems. I decided to get an affordable ($800.00 a month premium for my wife and I) but super-high-deductible policy as a "safety net" before I started undergoing testing. My yearly per person max out of pocket was $10,000.00. So first up was a colonoscopy. Had I NOT had insurance, it would have been $2300.00, but because I DID have insurance (even though I had not met my deductible) they could only charge me the contract price - $390.00. The system is so broken, and there is SO much money changing hands at the top, that I don't see it ever getting better. Regards, DD
